data.title: Code Insiders on Ubuntu always has an available update

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
1. Download code insiders from `code.visualstudio.com`
2. Check for updates
3. There is an update available
4. Download and install code insiders again
5. There is still an update available

I've noticed this because of the popup.

- OS Version: Linux Ubuntu 16.04

1. Open VS Code
2. Open `Toggle Developer Tools`

data.body:

- VSCode Version:
1.12.1
- OS Version:
win7(with cygwin), and linux ubuntu 
Steps to Reproduce:
If I change filestat modes on files aka "chmod ugo-x dsfmocklist.py" vsc indicated diff, but it does not say
anywhere that this is the case. Discard changes do nothing either

Enclosed is a screenshot the M flag is set, but I cant see any changes, not any description execution bit having changed.

![vsc-diff-on identical-file](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11349883/25888050/dec46df8-3564-11e7-97a1-ad8dab310c5b.jpg)

plain git diff shows this (in cygwin on same dir)
mobj@BPOLMOBJ1:tools> git diff dsfmocklist.py
diff --git a/tools/dsfmocklist.py b/tools/dsfmocklist.py
old mode 100755
new mode 100644

git --version
git version 2.8.3

Bitbucket after commit and push shows this:
![vsc_changes-exec](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11349883/25888339/0e0e20a8-3566-11e7-808e-92552007d5b7.jpg)

data.title: Investigate Adding Timeouts on TSServer Requests
data.body:
Part of #24698

I believe that our communication channel with the TSServer can sometimes become jammed by a request that  receives no response. This shows up as a series of cancelled requests in the traces.

It is unclear why this is happening but one potential solution that I want to explore independently of TypeScript is to adding timeouts to some of our requests. If a response is not received within something like 5 seconds we should just give up on the request and send the next one

data.title: Use language mode at Cursor for onEnter Rules
data.body: Fixes #26351 **bug** For the code ```js const x = |; ``` with the cursor at the `|`, our existing TS/JS onEnter rules should change the code to: ```js const x = | ; ``` However we currently do not handle this case correctly. The root cause is the extra semicolon at the end of the line. This causes `getEnterAction` to think that we are in a javascript context for the onenter rules instead of in a `js-tags` context **fix** Pass in the column of the cursor when getting the language id to use for the onEnter rules instead of using the end of the line. This ensures we are in the `jsx-tags` language in the above case

data.title: Opening preferences should focus the cursor on the search box
data.body: I frequently open the preferences editor and start typing assuming the focus is on the search box, but the cursor was in the custom settings pane and I enter text in the editor.

data.title: Git changes preview should behave same as opening files
data.body: While clicking once on a changed git file it should open tab in preview mode while double clicking in new tab. Things get messy in editor and it is painful to close all opened tabs after reviewing changes. It would be nice to have this feature.

data.title: Preserve Newlines in Signature Help Documentation
data.body:
Fixes #26346

**Bug**
Signature help currently displays newlines in documentation differently than the suggest widget does. This results in inconsistent looking documentation

**fix**
Use `pre-wrap` for the signature help documentation the same way we do for documentation in the suggest widget

data.title: node/docker: restart loops under unexpected network/remote server conditions
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:
- OS Version: macOS

Given the following `launch.json`:

```json
{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [{
    "name": "Attach to MAGE instance (docker)",
    "type": "node",
    "request": "attach",
    "address": "localhost",
    "restart": true,
    "localRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
    "remoteRoot": "/usr/src/app"
  }]
}
```

Where the process to connect to is a docker container running locally.

If the container is running, the proper ports exposed but the remote process is not running (therefore, the debugger has nothing to connect to), the following happens:

![vscode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/592432/25883221/d100b3a6-3583-11e7-99c2-06f9f579c06f.gif)

**edit** To clarify, this is happening forever, in a loop - the panel keeps on popping up.

![screen shot 2017-05-10 at 1 29 23 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/592432/25883337/cbd035b8-3584-11e7-9c2c-eb2e0cf8c3e2.png)

I believe this is because Docker proxies the connection by first accepting a connection, then immediately closing it if the actual remote is not currently listening.

I am reporting this issue here instead of on Docker because I assume that technically, the same issue might occur if the remote server had something else listening on that port, for instance, resulting in a similar outcome - a loop of which the only two ways to get out of is closing VSCode or editing the launch config to set 'restart' to false.

I belive the behaviour here should likely be one of the following:

  1. Same as timeout: on unexpected failure, do not try to reconnect
  2. Request user attention: "Something bizzaro happen'd, what sh'd I do? (retry/stop)"
  3. Introduce a "maxRetryCount": fail a number of times, but no further.

data.title: SignatureHelp Displays Multiline Documentation Differently Than Completion Item Provider
data.body: For the code: ```js /** * a * b * c */ function foo(x, y) {} foo ``` The completion item for `foo` preserves the newlines: The signature help display does not: We should be consistent in these cases. This impacts #26290

data.title: autopep8 installed, does not run
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:
Version 1.6.1
Commit 9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e
Date 2016-10-13T15:43:46.054Z
Shell 1.3.7
Renderer 52.0.2743.82
Node 6.5.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I got a pylint warning and a syntax error. It is important to note that I had been using sublime, but I got a IndexError: tuple index out of range for a line of code I had just used in an earlier version of the same code without complaint. I wanted to compare it on vscode. Vscode has no issues with this tuple, but it is screaming bloody murder about this print function syntax error that sublime had no trouble with. Also note I tried this with and without sep= in there.
![vscode 2 2017-05-09 20-49-32](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5474426/25882707/58b1fd12-34fa-11e7-8aac-ab4690a931ec.png)

2. So now I try to fix this print syntax error, and vscode tells me to install autopep8, which I do. Except vscode thinks I didn't. See attached. 
3. Then I tried yapf, which is some alternative vscode mentions, but clicking that does absolutely nothing except remind me to install autopep8.
4. For what it is worth, when you look at the images, you will see that I was in a virtualenv. But when I try to actually run code, it puts me in a new terminal outside the virtualenv. Different issue, but still annoying.

data.title: Feature request: Indicate the number of instances selected
data.body: When I select an instance in vscode, I need know how many instances there are in the current file. For example, when I select one instance and press Ctrl+F2 to modify all instances, I have to know if there are instances where I don't see. So it will be very useful if there is an indicator to indicate the numbers.

data.title: # (Goto Symbol command) doesn't work on macOS
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.1 (f6868fce3eeb16663840eb82123369dec6077a9b, 2017-05-04T21:18:32.269Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.4|
|autorest|ms-vscode|0.12.2|
|appidocsnippets|myax|0.1.11|
|vscode-sort-json|richie5um2|1.9.0|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.7.0|
|vim|vscodevim|0.7.1|
|Material-theme|zhuangtongfa|2.7.3|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new directory `test`, and `code test`
2. Create a new file `foo.py` with content:
```python
class Foo:
    pass
```
3. Close the opened Tab, then press Cmd + T Go to Symbol `Foo`

It shows no matched symbols.

In some situation, even though it finds the symbol, press Enter to Goto will cause a problem, as this images shows:
![2017-05-10 10 51 53](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8706522/25881311/bae02d0a-356e-11e7-862e-27721ce16350.png)
As you can see the file path prefix is duplicated, and it undoubtedly cause failure of the goto command.

data.title: JavaScript suggestions are currently too intrusive
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type anything - the suggestions that come up may be filtered poorly, and block out desired snippets added by extensions

Related to this Stack Overflow question:  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/43850267/configure-visual-studio-code-suggestions/

It would be ideal to be able to see all sources for these suggestions, and be able to turn them off.  Or any other workarounds would be much appreciated too!  I selected the highlighted option in the image and tried to "go to definition" but none was found, so it appears to be really tricky tracking down the .d.ts file where these are coming from.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11261266/25877982/faae5754-34ec-11e7-9408-309569cc6383.png)

data.title: Add support for local history
data.body: I would love to be able to see my local history for a file like you can do in intelliJ.

data.title: Javascript intellisense in inline scripts from external references

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This request is to provide intellisense capabilities for referenced script tags on inline javascript, for example:

```
<script src="myJs.js">  
<script>
   myJs.IntellisenseGoesHere
</script>
```

Ideally typings files are also supported for an even better experience

I could not find an open issue on this so per @aeschli 's comment on the last ticket related to this #15377 , I am creating a new feature request here

data.title: persistent "configure excludes" prompt
data.body: - VSCode Version:1.12.1 - OS Version:Win10 I have HTML/JS project with ~300 JS files and ~200 html files. Even though I have a jsconfig.json that contains excludes, I continually get a "configure excludes" button on the status bar. Pressing it (and the subsequent prompt) opens the correct JSON file and temporarily hides the "configure excludes" button, but it reappears again after a several minute delay. I'm assuming the status button indicates a file count threshold has been hit for the project and that javascript intellisense is disabled or defeatured as a result. If so, is there a way to override the default? If not, what can I do to provide additional troubleshooting? jsconfig.json ```JSON { "compilerOptions": { "target": "ES6" }, "exclude": [ "node_modules", "**/test/", "**/.vscode/" ] } ```

data.title: Error: Command with Adding Initial Configurations
data.body:
There is an error dialog that pops up when adding configurations created via a command through the debug window. Trying to mimic this with the C++ extension: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-node-debug/blob/c31d0935a28df4b4b0c85b41a9da6ad7b30e2b5b/package.json#L128

After clicking on Add Configuration and then selecting the type on this dropdown. 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3953714/25873739/7ae1c31c-34c4-11e7-9c46-1c1353e78ce6.png)

Then this error appears.

![initialconfigerror](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3953714/25873650/370c1f3e-34c4-11e7-9764-86216a85d37f.png)

This can be resolved, specifically for our case, if you select a .c or .cpp file, before adding configurations.

Here is the stacktrace of the error:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3953714/25874761/dec9508a-34c8-11e7-9a07-5d1a43f95a2b.png)


- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 

Please email me if you want a vsix to repro. 

@pieandcakes
